On tis, 2009-02-24 at 12:45 +0000, majkic@... wrote:
> WOW. I'm really impressed with seriousness you approached to
> acceptance testing.
> 
> On the other hand it seems that much work was involved to make this
> acceptance framework work fine.

Well, I should say that the application sends one HTML file after
logging in and the rest is JavaScript working with the DOM - it's a RIA.
It's a first for me, a first for the client.

I've spent 40 hours to get the test agent and test conductor to work
properly. That's for the infrastructure and it's been running for 12
months with one hickup regarding XML-RPC (had to change the http client
from Sun's to some Apache variant). I don't think that's very much,
considering the alternatives that were available by then.

The bash script that deploys/undeploys have had some love as well, since
it pulls things off a maven repo (archiva) looking at metadata to get
what's latest, ~8 hours.

> I would like to make our Selenium tests work automatically from CI
> server (linux server without X), as any JUnit test would work. This
> way our Product Owner (yes, we're Scrumming) could write all necessary
> acceptance tests instead of descriptive acceptance criteria.

I'd like to see that too, running browsers headless. :)
(The test agents we use are setup on a VMware cluster, so the CI server
never launches anything requiring a GUI.)

HTMLUnit's becoming more and more competent regarding JavaScript
(framework) support. Crosscheck is interesting as well. 

> CI is executing "mvn clean install" periodically and it would be great
> if we could automate this process.
> 
> Any ideas?

Not really. The Selenium tests takes ~4 minutes to run. A full build
(compile, unit test, integration tests) takes about 5 minutes. We want
short feedback cycles and found it to be a good thing to separate the
selenium test run since it takes a lot of time with little feedback
while it runs (no early failure here).

/ Fredrik
